content: sweater flight 1 by ouisi hamilton for chattanooga yarncrafters a sampler of four traditional sweater construction methods sized to serve as coasters for your favorite beverage use sock minis or leftovers to make these charming tiny sweaters sweater flight 1 by ouisi hamilton for chattanooga yarncrafters page # 2 materials each sweater uses 11-14g/45-65y/40-60m sock yarn for the two colorwork sweaters select high-contrast one dark one light yarns in solid semisolid or tonal colorways us 2/2 75mm needles a set of 5 dpns is recommended especially to keep track of raglan increases but you can use magic loop or any other method you prefer for working at a small circumference you will need another needle of the same size to work the three-needle bind off of the set-in sleeve sweater yarn needle and scissors for finishing gauge sock yarns vary in thickness and density these samples were worked at a gauge of 28 stitches and 40 row over 4 /10cm in stockinette stitch adjust your needle size up or down so that the sweaters have an appropriate amount of density and drape abbreviations bobble bind off m1l make one left increase cc contrast color m1r make one right increase cdd centered double decrease mc main color co cast on p purl increase increase rem remaining k knit sl slip k2tog knit two together decrease ssk slip slip knit decrease kfb knit front and back increase sts stitches general pattern notes links to video tutorials on stranded colorwork and intarsia are on the cover page of those two patterns see last page for links to tutorials for other techniques used in the patterns work all bind offs in pattern continue stockinette stitch or ribbing while binding off because these sweaters are so tiny the seams are disproportionately thick instead of blocking the individual pieces before seaming the patterns that involve seaming are first assembled and then blocked to keep them as flat as possible so they serve their function as coasters sweaters made to fit real three-dimensional bodies are assembled after blocking to block soak finished sweater in tepid water for 20 minutes press the water out and roll in a towel to remove more water smooth sweater out and leave flat to dry thanks to ravelry testing pool testers allisonkatryna divavonpurl franeen meg2cats thisdebknits tnbirdmom and wickedgoodshari sweater flight 1 by ouisi
